respondent.name: Y & H CORPORATION, DBA THE MOONLIGHT CAFE.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: We'll hear argument first today in Arbaugh v. Y & H Corporation. Mr. Joseffer.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Mr. Schwartz. Excuse me. Mr. Schwartz.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: So you say -- so now it's essentially redundant. Now that 1331 has no jurisdictional amount, no amount in controversy, the jurisdictional provision in title VII is just going over the same territory. It doesn't add or detract. Is that so?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: In the first sentence, but not in the venue part.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Which is not subject matter jurisdiction, which is what we're concerned with here.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: What about the argument, though, that when you're talking about a threshold question like coverage, who the statute covers, and it's quite different from the cause of action cases, many of which you rely on in your brief?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: It's more a question 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 of -- of whether or not the -- there's been a violation of title VII. It seems to me that the number of employee issue is whether you're covered at all, whether you have to conform your conduct to that law. Your question -- your -- your case of whether someone has been discharged or not just goes to whether there's been a violation.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: But in City of -- in City of Kenosha, of course, the Court went beyond the jurisdictional grant and it said that the definition of the term person in 1983 raised a jurisdictional question.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: What's the practical consequence of the one or the other? Number one, if you don't raise it below, you can still raise it on appeal if it's jurisdictional. Right?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: And number two, the -- if it's a jurisdictional question, it would be decided by the -- by the judge rather than by the jury?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: But that's always the case. I mean, why -- you know, if those disadvantages -- those disadvantages will always exist. So why would Congress ever make something jurisdictional rather than simply making it an element of the cause of action? You understand what I'm saying? I mean, that's always a consequence.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: And yet, you -- you acknowledge that some things are jurisdictional.

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: Well, but what's the rule that you suggest we look to in deciding whether a provision is jurisdictional? Because, as the Chief Justice pointed out, in 1983 cases where the question is whether the defendant is a person, we've held that is jurisdictional. So what is the rule in telling us 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 when we should treat something as jurisdictional?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: What would you call this? Would you call 15 or more employees an element of your claim that you must prove?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Or there could be an affirmative defense and you're not claiming the latter.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: But you're -- you're accepting that it is your burden rather than the employer's to show that the employer had fewer than 15 employees.

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: More than.

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: Did you establish that in the course of the proceedings?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: I was going to ask what -- how does the waiver work? Suppose the judge pre- verdict says, you know, I'm concerned that there are less than 15 employees. Can the plaintiff say, oh, well, now, Your Honor, you can't get into that? They waived that. They didn't raise it. I mean, how does that work?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Under your theory of the case?

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: Well, but if it's your burden to prove it, how can it be waived by the defendant? I don't understand your theory. 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: You mean the judge just has to watch the case sail over the waterfall and --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Well, in my case nobody mentions it but the judge.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Yes, and the -- and the judge calls it sua sponte to the attention of the parties.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Well, wait. You -- you 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 pleaded -- you pleaded that -- that the defendant was -- was an employer under the act. Right?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: And it's the definition of employer that says he has to have more than -- more than 15 employees. So, in effect, you -- in making your complaint, you -- you at least implied and maybe said that this person is an employer under the act. So it seems to me at that point the -- the burden shifts to the other side to say -- the burden of going forward of saying no, this person isn't an employer under the act, and if they say nothing, then they've accepted what -- what your complaint on its face says.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I knew you would. (Laughter.)

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: But -- but maybe -- but that doesn't sound like a reasonable agreement. All you -- so you file one sentence saying this person violated title VII. Are you impliedly including all of the allegations of what constitutes a violation of title VII because if you didn't allege every particular element, it wouldn't be a violation of title VII? That's not how pleading works. 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: In your pleadings, did you say he's an employer?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Did you use the term employer?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Okay.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: How does it -- you -- you told us of your extensive experience. How does the numerosity requirement usually come up? You've accepted that it's an element of your claim rather than an affirmative defense the defendant must plead and prove. So how does it ordinarily come up? Does it -- because defendant answers and asserts that it has fewer than 15 employees?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: That's true in a lot of areas. I think of admiralty. If there's an issue of admiralty jurisdiction that questions whether an injury is caused by a vessel in navigable water, you often have extended litigation over that jurisdictional question.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Does it -- does it have to be resolved preliminarily? Why can't you leave the jurisdictional question to be decided at the conclusion of the trial with all the other questions? Is there some rule of law that says that a jurisdictional question must be confronted before the trial and before the merits? Indeed, most jurisdictional questions are reexamined as the trial proceeds. That is, you know, initially the court will say, yes, there appears to be jurisdiction on the basis of the pleading. Then if there's a motion to dismiss, yes, there -- there appears to be jurisdiction on the basis of the affidavits. But then if the trial proceeds and it turns out that, in fact, there isn't jurisdiction, the court dismisses. So why couldn't this jurisdictional question always be handled that way? Just -- just leave it to be resolved during the trial. It wouldn't slow anything up.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Okay. So this is a third consequence of the jurisdictional issue.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: If the issue is jurisdictional, all the pendant State claims don't belong there and they've got to be chucked out; whereas, if it just goes to the merits, the pendant claims are properly before the court.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: That's an important consequence.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, Mr. Schwartz. Now Mr. Joseffer.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Mr. Joseffer, maybe you can raise the podium a bit so the microphone works better. The other way.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: What -- what about the EEOC having typed the question jurisdictional for administrative processing purposes?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Interpreted section -- the use of the word person in section 1983.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: So City of Kenosha was just kind of a silly waste of time.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: 1331 was applicable there as well. Right?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: I'm sorry. What have juries been determining?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Right.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: The -- the question was whether the truck drivers counted as employees because if they did, they'd have enough?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: But that's the -- that's a consequence of a determination that it's jurisdictional in any case. Right?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: I mean, if you had a case where you didn't dispute that the issue was jurisdictional and there had been a jury trial on the pendant State law claims, we'd still have to throw that out. Right?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, Mr. Joseffer. Mr. Prendergast, we'll now hear from you.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: There was no -- there was no allegation that the plaintiff was employed by your client?

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: Was the --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Was the word employer used in the pleadings?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: No. I'm just asking the really formal question. Was the word employer used to refer to your client at any point in the pleadings?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Do we have the complaint in --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Was there an allegation that the company, petitioner, or whatever it was -- that they violated the act?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: All right -- I guess that -- they must have thought that there were 15 or more employees because otherwise you wouldn't have.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Was that denied?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: You denied it. Then they presented evidence, and their evidence was A, B, C, D, E. And I guess then you presented some contrary evidence, and you didn't present any evidence that he wasn't an employer. So I guess the odds are he was.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: And if the odds are he was, they win in the absence of any evidence.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Then I guess maybe you could have appealed on that point. So did you?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Then I guess it's waived unless it's jurisdictional. So we're back to the 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 jurisdictional question.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: I never heard of a point on the merits that if you -- you think you're right. It's right on the merits, the element of the offense. You don't think they proved it, but unfortunately, you don't raise that in the appeal.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: And did you win or lose on that?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: What other aspects of title VII do you think are jurisdictional?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Do they hold that the plaintiff must allege the employer is not an Indian tribe? I'm over here.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Over here. (Laughter.) 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: I say in -- in those case that you just cited, did they hold that the plaintiff must allege that the employer is not an Indian tribe?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Do you interpret those cases as, in fact, holding that if there was a trial and a judgment in favor of the plaintiff against what turns out later to be an Indian tribe, that after the case is taken up on appeal, the Indian tribe can have the judgment set aside?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Did it, in fact, come up in that posture in the case? It has already been mentioned that the word jurisdiction has many, too many 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 uses. Did it -- did the question come up in the Indian tribe cases as it did here after the case was fully tried and after there was a jury verdict for the plaintiff?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: When -- if -- if it's brought up promptly, it really doesn't matter, does it, whether you label it 12(b)(1) jurisdiction or 12(b)(6), failure to state a claim? It goes out either way. When it is consequential is when you bring it up, as you did here, after you lose on -- at the trial.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Mr. Prendergast --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: -- my problem with -- with your -- your contention is that I don't know how it is that you -- that you intuit that this one definition is jurisdictional. I mean, the definition -- the -- the 15 employee limit is -- is part of the definition of employer in section 701.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: There are 13 other definitions in section 1701. For example, it defines on the basis of sex. Now, if -- if you contest whether a particular remark or a particular practice of the employer was -- fell within that definition, was on the basis of sex or not, would you say that the court had no jurisdiction?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Will you challenge -- well, why are you challenging jurisdiction when you're -- when you're saying the -- the definition of -- of employer has not been met, but you are not challenging jurisdiction when you say the definition of on the basis of sex has not been met. Why -- why pick on one rather than the other?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Yes, I -- I understand that.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: That -- that's what it comes down to.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: But how do you know --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: If both definitions in section 701 --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: -- why does one of them express one thing and another not express --

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: But the practical consequences of affirming here are severe in terms of handling these cases. And we've pointed out in some recent cases of ours that we've been a little sloppy in the past in using the word jurisdiction. So it looks to me like there are many indicators that would point to not treating the 15 employee requirement as one of subject matter jurisdiction.

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: Yes, but it's entirely in the hands of the defendant to raise some objection. Who knows better than the employer how many employees the employer has had? I mean, it's totally within your capacity to say, wait a minute --

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: -- we didn't have 15.

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: Were you representing this employer at the time?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: What's -- what's wrong with the rule? We're not dealing with article III here. What's wrong with the rule that if Congress doesn't put it in the jurisdictional section, it's not jurisdictional?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: It would make the future cases a lot easier to decide.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Well, it's --

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: May I go back to Zipes? In Zipes, the Court was faced with the -- the word jurisdictional had been appended to the statute of limitations. I think that was true of the way the EEOC spoke of the rigid time limit, that it was mandatory and jurisdictional. And then the Court explained in Zipes that a strict time line doesn't mean that it's jurisdictional. You can have a rule that's rigid, but it doesn't determine subject matter jurisdiction. And that's what Zipes tried to explain. The Court in Zipes was faced with a number of cases that had used that term to describe the time in which you must bring the action, mandatory and jurisdictional.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Yes, but now we know it's -- EEOC has changed.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: But why -- now that we do have Zipes, why should the number of employees be treated any differently than that rigid time line in -- in Zipes?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: But that was a pendant jurisdiction case. Wasn't Aldinger --

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Well, you just used an 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 interesting word because there are litigants who can claim complete immunity from liability, but that immunity, whether it's absolute or qualified, doesn't go to the court's subject matter jurisdiction. It has to be raised in those cases as a defense.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Or leave it to the States that often do cover smaller shops. 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Well, that -- that argument doesn't apply to absolute immunity cases, and yet in absolute immunity cases, once again, it's clear there's jurisdiction. There's simply immunity. The immunity doesn't depend on any particular facts.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: But we have to determine whether he's acting as a prosecutor. Sure. We have to determine whether the President was acting in a presidential capacity, but that's not the kind of fact inquiry that you were talking about with respect to the 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 -- qualified immunity.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: But I -- I don't see why the same argument can't be made with respect to prosecutors. It is clear that if -- if an individual is acting in a prosecutorial capacity and enjoys the appointment as a prosecutor, that at least the -- the system -- we're not necessarily talking about Congress here. The system says there -- there should be, as a categorical matter, an -- an immunity from prosecution. And yet, that does not go to subject matter jurisdiction. And it seems to me that that is essentially the exact argument that you're making here, and I don't see why it should be any more sound here than it would be in the absolute immunity case.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: That's right.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Well, why can't get they get the protections through summary judgment?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Among other things, you -- you've got to do it up front.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Well, if -- if we're worried about dragging people into litigation, I presume Congress didn't intend, as a -- as a general matter, to allow the -- the situation that we've got here. One party has been dragged through a piece of litigation and, having lost, has decided it wants to take another 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 shot at getting out of the case. Surely you can't say that was within the contemplation of Congress' intent.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: My -- my point -- 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: -- my point is not --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: -- my point is not that Congress in some specific sense, when it establishes a jurisdictional requirement, does not intend the occasional costs that the system has to bear by virtue of treating that requirement as jurisdictional. My point simply is that if we are in -- in a situation in which it is not clear whether it's jurisdictional or not, and the issue can be raised, in effect, up front effectively through summary judgment, and in the alternative, can be treated -- and -- as -- as an ineffective fact element, and in the alternative, can be left, in effect, forever to be raised as a jurisdictional element. The fact that it can be treated effectively up front is one reason to think that Congress would probably have wanted that fact issue to be regarded not as jurisdictional but as elemental so that it can be gotten out of the way and the parties are not going to go through entire trials only to have the whole thing upset by a belated jurisdictional argument. That's my only point.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: In other words, it doesn't make a whole lot of difference.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I'm not sure that helps your case. 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 (Laughter.)

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Does it make a difference on the -- the -- does the categorization make a difference on the relevant time of the inquiry for the 15 employees? You have 16 employees when the discrimination takes place. By the time the lawsuit is filed, you've only got 14. Does it matter whether that's called jurisdiction or going to the merits?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Even -- even if it's a question of jurisdiction.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: It certainly matters for plaintiffs in this situation. 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: It certainly matters from the defendant's point of view too. In many of these cases, it's not clear whether the number 15 has been -- as in this case, you have delivery drivers. You have owners whose wives are employed in the business.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: From the -- from the point of view of a defendant who thinks I'm going to fight this case on the merits, but if I lose, I still have this ace up my sleeve.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: That sounds like a good reason why a court should think long and hard about categorizing this as a question of subject matter jurisdiction.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Well, it would be simultaneous. The jury -- the jury would have that question. Didn't I understand the attorney for the United States to say this is typical of what juries decide, was this person an independent contractor or an employee? 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, Mr. Prendergast.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Mr. Schwartz, you have 3 minutes remaining.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Do you think -- do you think it's possible that -- that Indian tribes could be jurisdictional but an employer couldn't? I mean, it seems to me the two the questions are quite different. An Indian tribe is always an Indian tribe. Right? And you're -- you're excluding -- just as a prosecutor is always a prosecutor. You're excluding a whole category of people. But you're -- you're not excluding 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 a category of employers here, are you? Because it's a -- it's a factual question, whether at the time of the alleged offense, the particular company was employing more than 15 people. It isn't that this company forever has immunity.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: So you're -- you're not arguing for the Indian tribes here.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: May I ask you if the practice of law has returned to normal in New Orleans?
